comments.commentBody: I find it appalling to hear from those who feel that anywhere in Manhattan where someone can live without making a lot of money can live is bad for the city.  Why shouldn't they have this right?  Wouldn't it be better if they could live closer to where they work rather than having to live farther out and make such long commutes that forces them to wake up earlier than they have to just to be on time?  Another thing is that I'm tired of hearing that this is prime real estate space that it's sitting on.  What exactly defines that may I ask because I feel that used pretty loosely?  The reason why Tishman Speyer hasn't raised the rents on Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village is mainly because they could raise them, but then they would have to give up their tax breaks they are getting for keeping them low.  Unfortunately, they can't have their cake and eat it to.  BTW, many keep forgetting that this isn't a public housing project and that rent stabilization or regulation, which isn't even subsidized, isn't the same as affordable housing, though that isn't the same as public housing either.  Some really need to know the different between all of those.  Also, there are plenty of other housing types, but I won't go into that because the list is pretty long for that.  Nevertheless, many of those living in this complex do have jobs, and they aren't trying to live for free.  In other words, why should NYC, especially Manhattan, be only a playground for the rich?
Bloomberg owned stuy town?

Why is someone greedy because they have lived and paid rent in their apt/ home for 30 years?
What makes them greedy?
Are you greedy because you have lived where you live?
I agree with the commentor who said you sound very unhappy.
Sorry for your confusion.
Get a dictionary it might help.

"We're saving taxpayers a lot of money"... by giving $77 Million in taxes away, and by "preserving" middle-class housing for 20 years, which will go by in a New York Minute? This is nothing to crow about.

"....I wonder if it's really worth putting up with anymore - what am I saying, OF COURSE IT IS, this is Manhattan we're talking about...."

Of course it is NOT, unless you are idea of life consists on watching reruns of "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous", but this time, watching it live and with the joke being on you.

".....People who belong to unions are opposed to unions. People on medicare are opposed to medicare....." etc.

As a foreigner that has spent decades in the States, I am still speechless when I read and hear what you describe. Only in the US can we witness the political victims cheering for their terminators.

That's a family of THREE, not a family of 1.  If it were a single person you could use that basic arithmetic but it doesn't work for 3 people because there are 3 people who eat, need healthcare, clothing etc.

It's not a REAL 2 bedroom. It's converted from a living room into a 2 bedroom.
It's not the 2 bedroom 2 bathroom Peter Cooper 2 bedroom either.
Don't feel so bad...it a mouse hole when they convert the living room into a bedroom.
When the air conditioner is on in the "living room" / 2nd bedroom, you need to keep the door of that room opened so you can feel the air!
Lame.
What's PT?

Sure, firefighters (in NYC, 90% of them are of white blue collar origins) are going to leave their 4 to 5 bedroom houses in Nassau, Rockland, Suffolk and Putnam counties to come and squeeze into  a 2-bedroom apartment in a city for whose multi-ethnic population they could not care less.
The article says that his death was lonely, not that he was a lonely person. One of his acquaintances suggests that he was depressed, but the author does not come to that conclusion...
Take away Citizens United and the noxious influence of Adelson and the Koch brothers, and this could be us!

Oh my... Fear is a strange deceiver.

As Thomas Merton reminded us, "We are all human." Behind those headscarves, those addicted neighbours and, yes, even the monied folks from China, are genuine humans doing their best. As I'm sure you and your 'old stock' ancstors do and did.
Winner: CANADA and the World!!!!

The philosophic difference is between the concept that we are
Family, or we are Individual.

The idea of humanity as collective family is illustrated by the biblical question, "Am I my brother's keeper?" The biblical answer is, "Yes, because he is your brother". As Jesus said, "Who is my mother, and who are my brothers?" His rhetorical question answers itself: all humanity is family and we are collectively and individually responsible for the welfare of this family.

The contrasting philosophy is expressed pointedly by Ayn Rand's take on Individualism and its rejection of altruism, a concept she developed by enduring the madness of Stalin's Soviet Union at its worst - something that was a distortion and far distance from Karl Marx's original intent of an egalitarian socialism. I take care of myself, and good luck to you on your separate path.

Taken into the political arena the issue lends itself to the sense of the collective - the main purpose of government - to maintain the stability and safety of the society overall. But what of other societies in the throes of self-destruction? Do we sacrifice the lives of of our young soldiers and our treasury? To what end, exactly? What is the realistic outcome?

These questions are never easy, and the answers seldom accurate.
would you like to say why you feel so strongly about the burka? comparing it to FGM?

Replying to my own comment as I'd like to answer replyers

Pierre Trudeau started the non-sustainable programs decades ago, as did most occidental leaders at the time. He wasn't an anomaly, to his credit. Not demonizing the person either, I actually a fan of of Trudeau father's vision of the country

Just wish there'd be a better way to monitor government spending. Seems like those are always the worst hangovers

As for protecting the social programs of the country: that's the beauty of our Parliament and mutli-party system, and my favourite (booyah Canadian spelling) government of all: a minority government; i.e. the sum of elected officials not part of the ruling party is more than the sum of the ruling party

These governments tend to get the least amount of (partisan) bills past... and end up doing just what government should do: nothing fancy, nothing expensive, just run the country while being considerate and polite to other elected officials

My biggest wish would be that minority governments can't just call a new election on a whim, and that they have to govern a minimum of 4 years. Now that would be some seriously civilised governing
If nothing else, you are rid of the hate-baiting. That is worth an awful lot.

As a Canadian liviing in British Columbia it took a lot of thought before I voted Liberal. The old Trudeau was not very well liked on the West Coast but it was time for a change for our country. Harper forgot his roots and became too dictatorial and I just was tired of the party.
I am looking forward to the Liberal promise of not buying the F35's and putting that money into ships for the Royal Canadian Navy as they are desperately needed. I am a little worried where the money is going to come from for all the election promises but still am looking forward to a bit of change for the country. I hope the Conservatives will elect a more moderate leader and be ready for the next election.

You're not teaching your children well, Francois. To blame the country's debt problems on Pierre Trudeau, who left office 30 years ago, is preposterous. Since Stephen Harper and the Conservatives first took power in 2006, the federal debt has risen by more than $150 billion, wiping out the reduction in debt achieved under Liberal Prime Ministers Jean Chretien and Paul Martin. Indeed, Harper's contributions to Canada's federal debt exceed those of all Liberal governments combined.
You're blaming the Liberals for Harper's disasters.

Mark,
The media would have pilloried Layton if he were still alive. Mulcair simply spoke the truth, a cardinal sin in politics. Justin is not his father and this is not 1965 when Pierre Trudeau ran as one of the three wise men. Job One was getting Harper out. I have lost an excellent NDP member of parliament but here in Quebec things happen too quickly for us old geezers and maybe a vin ordinaire Prime Minister is what we need right now.
One would think, but one would also think that Nader voters would have voted a bit more strategically in Florida...
It is the way to go.
Thanks...we're pretty happy about it too!

True and we wanted a change.  This coming from a conservative who was tired of the autocratic rule of Harper.  Change is good for every democracy and hopefully the Conservatives will come back with a new, better leader.  Justin Trudeau I hope you govern with a more open government than the outgoing one.
hey canada - you get what you deserve
It brings joy to me!

I sadly have to agree with you. we travel extensively in the US and quite love the people but they don't have a clue about our country. When I say I from British Columbia they start thinking South America if I try just BC then I am from Boston College! Great people but must have no geography or history other than the US. In Canada we get quite a bit of history of Canada, US and of course the UK. I think it is important to try to learn as much as your neighbors as possible.
Good luck in your upcoming elections. Cannot believe the amount of money that is wasted in holding them though.
